title: Hamilton star Daveed Diggs in talks to voice crab Sebastian in live-action Little Mermaid
text:
Disney's live-action Little Mermaid has become one of the most highly-anticipated projects in Hollywood.

And although the movie has found its Ariel, most of the other roles have yet to be officially cast.

Daveed Diggs is the latest star who's in talks to join the film, as he's up for the role of Sebastian.

Digg it: Daveed Diggs is the latest star who's in talks to join the live-action Little Mermaid, as he's up for the role of Sebastian

Disney fans will remember Sebastian as a Jamaican crab and King Triton's trusted advisor.

Diggs found his breakout role when he originated Thomas Jefferson and Marquis de Lafayette in the iconic Broadway musical Hamilton.

He has since transitioned to film and television with roles in The Get Down, Black-Ish and Velvet Buzzsaw.

The 37-year-old is next set to star alongside Jennifer Connelly in TNT's series adaptation of Bong Joon-ho's 2013 Chris Evans-led dystopian thriller Snowpiercer.

Beyoncé protégé Halle Bailey, landed the scarlet-haired half-fish leading role of Ariel in July.

The classic Disney title follows the young mermaid who longs to walk on land, as she makes a deal with evil seawitch Ursula.

Melissa McCarthy has been all but confirmed to play the fabulous tentacled antagonist, while Javier Bardem is in talks to play King Triton.

Awkwafina and Jacob Tremblay have also been announced, respectively voicing Scuttle and Flounder.

Harry Styles notably turned down the role of Prince Eric, telling The Hollywood Reporter: 'I want to put music out and focus on that for a while. But everyone involved in it was amazing. So I think it’s going to be great.'

Meanwhile, Krypton's Cameron Cuffe and A Dog's Way Home star Jonah Hauer-King have recently tested for the romantic lead.

13 Reasons Why star Christian Navarro was recently turned down for the role after campaigning on Twitter.

He updated fans about the controversial decision, while throwing shade at Disney: 'Disney said no. They'd like someone more "European." And we know what that means.'

Meanwhile, the film has faced criticism for casting a black actress as Ariel, sparking the hashtag #NotMyAriel.
